And you will have seen that we have announced a noticeable increase in the payback ratio, and that is one way of returning funds to our shareholders and the payout ratio, the dividend, it has increased.
[French]
You may remain seated.

One question, general question, in the line of what the CFO has said, you have a good structure, a good balance sheet for this year, compared with last year, it has produced a lot of cash, given what you have said, we believe that this will continue. I would like you to tell us, because I'm more positive than what I've heard on your value, 2009 had a difficult context. These are not problems for the company. We fully agree with you, Jean-Paul Agon. So, this will generate cash, in the five to 10 years to come, is there a division that you plan to develop more than the others? Do you plan major acquisitions?

Thank you very much for this excellent question. I fully agree with you. I would like to answer on what you've said. You may agree or disagree, but my feeling deep down inside is that 2009 was a key year. It's a year – for 18 months the cosmetics market stopped. L'Oréal stopped – was interrupted in its growth and sales at the profit end, but it's a key year because it's a year during which we changed a lot of things. We changed our strategy. We strengthened the company regarding growth drivers in terms of research, redefined the development strategy, redefined a clear mission for the group, which is to go find these billion consumers since the market is switching towards the new markets. And as user, I agree that 2009 was a key year and the very good news is that, that year is now behind us and we are now in 2010 and we have a clear strategy and strong ambition.

Coming back to your question, in terms of division, you've seen that we are on four parallel markets. This is important to understand in our business – the four channels, the four circuits are fairly parallel, and the role of each of our divisions is to maximize its growth, its market share in each of the distribution channels. And this is what they each do, and one division will be playing the role of the scout, so to speak, and that is the Consumer Products Division, where we open up new countries, such as Ukraine, Indonesia, Egypt, Pakistan, and others, or India. Obviously, it is through the Consumer Products that we are able to penetrate into the market, that we're able to concur these millions of new consumers and this is probably the division in which we're going to be investing the most in the years to come, because that is the division which will give us – open up our presence in these countries.

But each division has its plan, its strategy, its way of developing its leadership. Apart from Consumer Products, the three divisions are the leaders in their channel. Brigitte is the leader in dermal pharmacy. Her role is to widen her activity and globalize her activity. The Luxury Products Division is the leader in the selective distribution channel for luxury, and we wish to strengthen our leadership and Nicolas Hieronimus is the leader on Professional Products.

So if there really is a division where it is our feeling that the expansion will take place, will be there, it is that area because we have so much expertise and know-how in that channel that I think the road is wide open for growth for us. The challenge will be for Jean-Jacques to go looking for these billion new consumers, women and men, and he seems very confident and determined.

Now regarding cash, as Christian Mulliez indicated, we have a very good balance sheet. We have a very robust financial situation. Nobody's talking about us anymore. A year ago here commentators were saying, oh my god the number one priority for a company is to have a healthy balance sheet, a year later, it's gearing. Okay, that's the way it goes. But a robust balance sheet remains a good thing for a company. Gearing is down to 14%, and so you've seen the numbers, we have a very good balance sheet. We will be giving money back by increasing the dividend, but we also have a stash which will enable us to carry out acquisitions, small, medium, or large, which might show up in the years to come.
Thank you, sir.
Mr. Harold?

Good morning. I have two or three questions. First question on the gross margin, sales remained fairly low in the second half, but gross margin increased quite a lot. So, if there's an increase in sales again, could we have an idea regarding the impact on the gross margin and what will happen in 2010 and later? That's a good question for Christian.

Secondly, you said that you have more A&P expenses, you invest more, but you said that you wanted to know exactly what was the return on investment, you've investigated that issue. So, this is return on sales investment that you want to understand. Is that a new trend at L'Oréal, something new, which you're doing?
We've never thought of doing that before.

No, but joking apart. Honestly, is this a new issue? Is this a redoubling of effort we are talking about here or is it really something that you would engage in systematically, something you will want to understand exactly where your money goes, trying to increase the return on investment and reduce the cost when – the original return on investment and increase the costs, what that is. And you were talking about the cosmetic markets in 2009. You had made good predictions back then, good forecasts. So, what are your forecasts for 2010?

Yes, I'd like to thank you very much for your question. It is true that a year ago in this very room, I had said that the cosmetics market would end up on a slightly positive note. And there were some doubts amongst the analysts in this room, and yet my forecasts were correct.

So I would not venture to say that I'm always right, nevertheless, but I think – we think – today that the market should speed up further. But we should not regain our previous level of previous years. We had a market of plus 5%, if I remember correctly in 2007, and then plus 1% in 2008. And we should probably be in between 5 and 1%. So, probably plus 3% is a reasonable forecast.

This may be of interest to you, what we can see is that the mass market products have been on the increase in Western Europe, not in North America, not yet. There's a very strong growth of course, in new markets, which I've already said. Luxury markets are stable at a relatively high level in Western Europe, and not yet in North America. Maybe – well, January is slightly positive, so maybe there is a trend there. But a slight increase only for the time being.

Active Cosmetics, same thing. We have some uncertainties regarding hair salons. However, we're really waiting for the sales to go up and for the number of visitors to go up. But it will happen. It's all due, of course, to the mood of our consumers, and hopefully, people will get more optimistic and the sales will benefit from this.

Second point, of course, we didn't wait for 2009 to wonder about, as you said, where our money has been going, and the return on the money invested. I would like to maybe do away with the myth. When we say 30% of A&P costs, people get the impression that we're really playing with very large amounts of money, hundreds of millions of euros in advertising, and so on.

When we talk about A&P means, or sales view, we're talking about recurring investment in each and every distribution channel. And what we want to do is invest in order to allow for these brands to take off.

Take Active Cosmetics, for example. There's a fairly limited amount dedicated to advertising. Only Vichy is doing some advertising, but there's a very large part, for example, at La Roche-Posay for medical villages. I mean, this is not money that you throw out of the window and you don't know where it's going. It's very well targeted, very precise, it's very concrete.

We invest in hairdressers, for example. In luxury products, we have counters with salespersons. At the Galeries Lafayette, for example, you have to pay for the desk, you have to pay for the sales person, you have to pay for the samples, otherwise you can't have a footprint at a Galeries Lafayette department store. So, it's not like we're juggling with millions of euros. These are serious, recurrent investments we're talking about.

However, we should point out to the fact that there was a recession indeed, that the world has changed, and we have to take that on board. But the world is in flux, that's what Nicolas Hieronimus has been doing and he did this in a very smart way. Changing trends also create opportunities for changing attitudes and expectations on the part of our consumers. So, we have to readjust, we have to shift our investment priorities according to different criteria. That's exactly what we are going to do in all three divisions, in the other divisions – Nicolas has already done this – and paved the way for this trend in 2010. Maybe Mr. Lebel should tell us more about it.

Regarding the consumer division, first of all, how do we buy our media space? That's very important and it's a good measurement. You know that when there was a period deflation, it was less expensive. In Western Europe, it's 8 to 9%. But we have negotiating clout, strong negotiating clout, which means that we have double-digit percentage here. We do roughly twice the market deflation rate.

Just to give you an indication in 2010, we think that there will be a further improvement in our media purchasing condition. So, that's the first measurement that we can talk about, the measurement of our performance and the efficiency of our investments. So, our money is money well spent.

Another factor is very simple. You know that our brands are centralized, product and brand creation happens in Paris in a centralized way. The same film of the same video will be shown the world over. Whereas a few years ago it wasn't like that. It's not like every country would shoot its own film, but it was fairly often that we would have film production costs that would increase four-fold, five-fold, six-fold to maybe present to the world over. So, now we have streamlined our costs.

We are also using top-notch technology, so that means that we have a good evaluation method for the types of campaigns that we launch. We have a number of weeks during which these campaigns are shown, several methods can be used to look at the quality of what has been produced. So, we want to optimize the types of media campaigns that we're launching.
The list is long. I mean, there are many such indicators. But media purchasing, media space purchasing obviously is the – where most of the efforts are focused.
A few words, Marc and Brigitte maybe?

Yes, we've already started with this in 2009. There are two examples that I can quote. In Asia, we have shifted. We have moved our media plans in 2009. We have split up our TV investments. For example, this had a very strong impact on second quarter plus 7% in the first half, plus 12% in Asia for sales. And this was true for China, Korea, Taiwan we've invested a lot in TV media space purchasing.

And a second example in Europe, we worked with an outside firm and engaged in a major large scale study for the optimization of our A&P resources, what Jean-Paul was talking about. We have the beauty advisors now present in department stores, over 3,000 of them in our European department stores. This has led to a very precise reorganization per country, per brand, per department store of the – what we want to do with our beauty advisors.
So we have had improvement in terms of the cost and in terms of the quality of service. So, this started in 2009, we're doing the same thing in the United States right now.
Brigitte?

Yes, quite a lot of activities were carried out. I would like to go through – first of all, use of the media space. What Jean-Jacques was talking about is something that we've benefited from at corporate level.

Secondly, everything to do with advertising on the point-of-sale. For the last two years or so, we've invested 30% of our total resources, everything to do with displays, counters, and so on. Now, these costs have been reallocated to training all of our pharmacy personnel and staff. And we've also fine tuned the allocation of all of our resources, customer-by-customer. We can now follow customer-by-customer, even the potential customer, whether we have very good allocation of our resources. So, this is something that is done permanently and on an ongoing basis.

Yes, indeed and you're right, it's a key point. And we have 30% of your overall sales that go, that feed the A&P expenses, obviously ongoing questioning and analysis and assessment of the productivity of all of these investments. You want to of course, spend your money in a smart way. All of this ongoing evaluation process is absolutely key. So, this is something that's close to our heart. There was a question on gross margin in the second quarter.

Yes is absolutely right. We managed to show an improvement of our gross margin despite the drop in volumes in 2009, which means that chances are that with an increase, likely increase of volumes in 2010, gross margin would further grow.

And just a few comments on this, if I may. The productivity will probably be once again very positive, especially because there are many efforts being devoted to increasing productivity; and we also have reorganization plans.

I quoted a number of figures in that respect in my presentation. I indicated an average payback duration of three years, so it's not easy to do in this calculation, especially because you have half of the savings that go to the sales and half that go to the SG&A, so that's a positive trend. Something that is not as certain, purchases, will we be able to save as much on purchasings in 2010 as we did in 2009. It's a bit premature to answer this question.

And the third factor which by nature is uncertain, but we've just got off to a good start for the time being, everything to do with the currency situation. You know that we have 34% of our sales in euros, which means that 66% of the remaining sales are not in euros. From our perspective, the euro has done well, since over the last six or eight weeks – and this indeed is a positive factor as far as our brands are concerned. So, we shall see later in the year how it turns out.
You, sir?

I have a minor question, to complete what you said about advertising costs and I've another question regarding your new brand, the Yves Saint Laurent brand that you want to turn it into a major world brand. So just a little complement regarding the A&P costs, have you changed in your budgets the share of advertising on a point-of-sales? Generally speaking, independently of the price situation, we know and professionals say so that it is on the point-of-sales that half of the purchases are decided. So you should not have reduced your budget on that. So that's the small question. And there is another question. Talking about the launching of this new brand, I don't really understand because you already have a lot of global brands across your different business lines. Do you still need yet another global brand and what will make it different from the other brands that you have? What will be the differentiating factors? Were there gaps that you needed to fill or is it something that will add in a quantitative way if not qualitative, what will be the specificity of this new brand?
No problem, with great pleasure, Marc will do this, I'm sure, with a great deal of pleasure.

Yes, of course. Well, obviously we had two major world brand, Lancôme, which is the leading luxury brand worldwide and Armani, which is also a major fragrance brand mainly, leading in the fragrance position where we had no brand of French designer. This was a missing piece in the puzzle. And Saint Laurent allows us to fill this gap in a way and do this very well and this gives us two different opportunities.

First of all, the opportunity to develop on the large category of women's fragrances and that's what we've done, but it could be after the acquisition with the launching of Parisienne, which is a fragrance which has been doing very well, very successfully everywhere. The December sales were incredible, ranking sixth in France on the French market, for example, in December. So a lot of growth opportunities on the main category, which is women's perfumes and then of course, another opportunity for us now is to complete our positions in the make-up range with a lot of prospective growth for the future. So indeed, there is a great deal of complimentarity and a net contribution, a positive contribution to our brand portfolio.
Unfortunately, the question cannot be heard.

Well, this is something we won't tell you. This is something we can't betray. But anyway, if there is one brand on which we have no doubts when it comes to striking the right complementarities that's precisely it. It is a great brand. A great, the great opportunity that Yves Saint Laurent gives us is that the brand image of Yves Saint Laurent, the magic behind Yves Saint Laurent was much greater than the actual sales. So if we're not too bad, we will be able to capitalize on this brand and turn it into one of the leading global beauty brands, and we will be able to compete with other French brands by famous French designers, you could even know what I'm referring to. So there is a huge potential to be tapped. We are highly, highly confident with Yves Saint Laurent. There is a great deal of complimentarity with our existing portfolio. Jean-Jacques, may be you could say something about the first question, the advertising on the point-of-sale.

Yes, we don't want to reduce, but we want to optimize it, make-up obviously is sold on the point-of-sale, we don't want to have less advertising. We want everything to be more beautiful, more attractive, and we want the sales person to sell as many products as possible, but we can maybe again on purchasing prices, when we do promotions we have to be careful that we don't have to destroy anything. So optimization is always something we can do. There are very significant potential gains to be derived from this. Emmanuel, you had a question?

Good morning, Emmanuel from the Société Générale. I have four questions. The first two on the margins and overall financial results, we are talking about growing results and profit in 2010, do you think you will be able to improve on your adjusted EBIT margin as of 2010 also?

It's a bit early, isn't it? It's a bit premature to answer this question. I don't think that we generally speak and talk about such things. I think that you, it's going a bit too far. Some of the meaning of my questions is as follows, is priority given to internal growth or to margins, are you expecting first of all, some kind of strong internal growth before you actually move on to trying to increase your margins. Well once again, it's a bit premature isn't it, this is only the 15th of February. So we have trends. It's very early, I mean, to tell you about what will happen. Our objective for 2010, however, is indeed to resume with organic growth in 2010 to continue improving our operating structure and to increase our results.

Now, if you want to look at the actual structure of the P&L, you have increased the A&P cost for the last two years as a percentage of the sales. Have we now reached a threshold in 2009 or could the A&P cost go beyond the current level?

We think that we are at the right level. We don't want to be too rigid at the same time. One of the consequences of the last two years is that we don't want rigid structures. Despite the relevance and friendliness of your questions, we don't want to make any firm and definite commitments. We want to – we don't want to set things in stone once and for all. We're just giving you indications on the way we see things, but don't take them as firm and definite commitments, except when it comes to growing our business obviously. When it comes to the operating structure of our business, we consider today that we've reached a good level and we feel that it's very reasonable to keep this level in 2010. I mean, this is obviously in rough terms.
You said the payback period is three years, is 2009 part of these three years or are you talking about 2010, '11, '12, what three years are you talking about?
Parts of it is already in 2009, but it's a small share.
How can we distribute this through the three years?

Well, maybe the last six months of 2009 and then on from there three years after that, we could look at this calculation. You had 120 million professions in 2008, 220 in 2009 and if you consider that we have half of what could have done – engaged in 2009, that was in 2008, you will reach the right figures.

There is another point which you mentioned which I think was very significant. You said that for consumers the value for money aspect was getting more important than ever before. I didn't say more than ever before. I just said that they are essentially growing importance maybe, yes, to this aspect. We are convinced at L'Oréal that consumers are intelligent, are smart. It's not new that they should be interested in the value for money aspect. It is nothing surprising. I simply said that because of the recession possibly this trend got even stronger. This trend towards value for money doesn't mean that we want low prices and evidence of this is the new innovation that I've presented to you.
I find it's interesting to see that L'Oréal was a pioneer in terms of innovation. You were ahead of your competitors.

We still are. We still are because remember the last three innovations that we talked about in 2009 are light years ahead of our competitors, if I may, say, in terms of coloring, skincare and in many different areas indeed the major breakthroughs of the cosmetic industry in 2009 were achieved by the L'Oréal Company.

That's precisely the point that I wanted to insist on. Your competitors more than ever before may have woken up in terms of innovation. I'm not saying that their innovations are at the same level as L'Oréal, but L'Oréal was the only company at the time, L'Oréal was interested on innovation more than others. But your competitors over the last few years, we get the impression, have really woken up. At least they say that they have, they say that innovation is key and they say that the share of new products in their overall sales is greater. So the question is what will you do vis-à-vis consumers? How will you bring it home to them that they – you presenting products with good value for money?

Yes, well. Deep down you're right. All of the players in the cosmetic industry have understood a basic truth of this business. It's an offering market. It's a market where consumers are always interested by quality, by innovation, by performance, and so on. That's what brings the market forward and always has brought it forward. We produced a beautiful book called 100,000 Years of Beauty, for the last 100,000 years consumers are always looking for a beauty product that will outperform the previous one they had. So, cosmetics by nature is a market that is driven by innovation. So, everybody has understood – has finally, grasped this truth.

The second point, I would like to make is that the true competitive edge is not so much the fact that we should communicate about innovation where we want to have better performance and quality. That's the true obsession of our laboratories and our businesses, business lines. We don't want to just be telling nice stories to our consumers. We would also want to make sure that in each category of product we have a new, leading edge product that is different from competitors with the highest level of performance that goes further than others and it will give consumers a better level of satisfaction. Because don't forget that, as far as cosmetics are concerned, repurchasing happens very quickly and a product is a resounding success only if it is purchased again by consumers. So, consumers are voting every day with their feet; Génifique is a great success, not because there is a beautiful advertising behind it, but because deep down it is a great product that is purchased, repurchased, and hearsay plays a role in that respect.

So, that's what we want to do and that's where we've been increasing our R&D costs. We are convinced, more than ever before, as I said, in my little presentation that it is the difference of quality performance, efficacy, and safety that will really make a difference. It set us apart from our competitors and that's indeed what we have in mind, we are obsessed with this idea. Laurent Attal who is the new head of Research is obsessed with this idea. Jean-Francois Grollier had the same state of mind, that's what we have at the back of our minds all the time.

We're highly confident because we consider, rightly or wrongly, that we have the best research team worldwide, that we are devoting a lot of resources to the R&D, we are ahead of industry, we are ahead when it comes to genetic research, when it comes to stem cells research, hair care technical products, such as coloring, and we are going to keep this ahead of competition and amplify this gap with competition and it is thanks, to technological breakthroughs that we will be able to further ensure our leadership, vis-à-vis our competitors.

One last point at the end of 2009, can you tell us about the weight of the BRIMC countries and their growth like-for-like, compared to that in 2009 and will the Body Shop establish a foothold in significant markets, such as India and Brazil?

The Body Shop is already in India, yes, but not with a strong presence. Well, yes, gradually, we'll do that, we have some 20 shops I think in this country, in India and in Brazil, we have quite a lot of competitors in Brazil. So, we are not going to have Body Shop fight bloody battles there, you know, the return on the investments of Body Shop are also important and I don't think that profitability should be an issue. So, launching Body Shop against Beaute Carieau and Natur is not necessarily the wisest decision in terms of management for the Body Shop as a whole. So, we will send Body Shop to fight battles where we can increase and develop, we will see later. And for the BRIMC now.

So, the five BRIMC countries represented 14.2% of the sales and the like-for-like extension was 13%. So, you see that in 2009 this was interesting. China had growth close to 18%, Brazil went back to a very legitimate growth rate for a country, such as Brazil, India, is in full re-acceleration. And the latest news we've received were good because that's an average. But, towards the end of the year the numbers were closer to plus 60%. They come from a low sales figure. So, it's normal that they should accelerate to catch-up. The other good news is that Russia picked up towards the end of the year, oil at $75 a barrel has helped a bit, and so, they're returning to growth. Consumer products is at plus 16% and we had a positive beginning of the year in Russia. Mexico is also recovering. Mexico is more tied to the American economy, but they are returning to growth also.

The important thing is that new markets is not only the BRIMC countries, but countries that I was mentioning earlier, Ukraine, Indonesia, which are also major countries. Indonesia has a population of 250 million inhabitants, it's the Brazil of the ASEAN region. There are new countries which have a tremendous potential and where our acceleration is going to be very productive. There is a question from the room next door, room two.

Good morning. Eric Blanc, Tradition Securities. I'd like to ask a question on something that has some importance, which is Sanofi. If you look at the – if it were available for sale, you would have a net positive cash, your co-shareholder assigned 2 billion shares a year, total. So, could you tell us the numbers at the end of the year, is there a price level at which you would change strategies and could that funding give you a fifth leg so to speak? Galderma or the Body Shop for instance, which you didn't mention as a leg. And has the valuation decreased? And what about the possible external growth possibilities?

Well Sanofi at December 31 in our balance sheet accounts for €6.2 billion, we hold 9% of that – of the company. We did not sell Sanofi shares in 2009 since the last sale, which had taken place about two years ago. We have remained clear on our position. We are a loyal shareholder of Sanofi, but this stake is there to fund the future needs of the group. And we will not indicate a price at which we would trigger an operation, as you can well imagine.
The real reason for selling Sanofi would be more an acquisition to fund rather than a share price.

Regarding acquisitions, we have always been very open to everything that comes up, Christian and his team are always very busy looking at all the acquisition dossiers that show up on the markets around the world and in all of the circuits, but we have always been very selective and we look into – more closely only into what we are seriously interested in. And, as indicated earlier, we ask ourselves 10 times whether such and such a company is interesting? Whether it adds to our brand portfolio? Is it a global brand? Will it be useful for our growth? There are a number of very demanding criteria which lead to our keeping only a few operations in the end.

But we are very open, we look at everything and, you know, this is a market, which is very fluctuant, it consolidates, de-consolidates, businesses come back on the market, and we have these financial means of carrying out the acquisitions that we would like to carry out. Ladies, I don't know who was first.
from Barclays Capital.
Hello.
I'm breaking out of the interpretation to ask a question in English.
Yes, that's very good.

Mr. Mulliez, would you please be so kind and walk us through the main drivers of the improvements in working capital of that have driven the reduction in net debt. And also, very importantly, could you give us an idea where you see the main drivers or main constituents in working capital moving next year? What will be the key moves behind there and what is your use of your free cash flow? Where are you going to invest it? Where can we see your shifting resources that you are going to put more towards faster growing markets? How can we see that reflected in your use of free cash flow? Thank you.
Very good. Christian?

As I have explained in my presentation, the improvement in – very strong improvement in working capital came from two drivers – two factors, the first one is, as you know, inventories which decreased significantly and we are confident that this driver should – this should be another driver for a possible improvement in 2010. The second factor was the improvement of the trade account receivables. I'm afraid to say that the turnaround of the business and the come back to growth should generate needs in working capital from the trade accounts receivable perspective. It's difficult to say what will be the variation of the working capital in 2010, but if you should consider that it should be something at least plus 200 million for working capital. It's likely to be in this order of magnitude. Then about the proceeds, the use of the free cash flow, as Jean-Paul explains, we're not close to a possible share buyback program as a principle, but we consider that the acquisition is suddenly a better way to improve the value of the company and the last point, as you've seen, we increased, significantly, the pay scale ratio in 2009 from 41% to 44%.
[French]

Sophie from La Tribune. Going in the same direction, I would like to know what would be the share of the Group's investment devoted to new markets in 2009 and possibly in 2010? And also, I would like to know why you are cannibalizing yourselves, so to speak? Code Jeunesse is very reminiscent of Génifique, such as Ôscillation from Maybelline is reminiscent of the Ôscillation from Lancôme. So, is that a strategy not to be overrun by your competitors?

Well, I think you've given the answer yourself. They are simple answers. When the L'Oréal Group has spent 10 years studying genomic applications in cosmetics, has taken a lot of leading edge, compared with competitors, obviously one wishes to optimize this. So, the first technology that was launched was launched by Lancôme and since it's an area of research rather than an active ingredient, a year after the launch by Lancôme on the basis of the cascading principle, we decided to also launch a product in the L'Oréal Paris line.

The active ingredients are totally different. I could give you one is active bifidus and in the Génifique and adenoside and cogent-S. So, the ingredients are different, the textures are different, the products are different. But there is the same work upstream in basic research at L'Oréal. So, this is important for us, this enables us to cascade down our major research efforts and investments when you look at 10 years of basic research, it's an area of research, I'm sure that our financial analyst friends here would be happy to see us capitalize on that. It's better, I think you would agree, that it's better for L'Oréal Paris to launch a competitor to the Génifique product, than if it were to be a competitor of L'Oréal.

Investments in the emerging new markets; we don't have the exact distribution, the exact breakdown of the investment, but in terms of investment, most of our investments are in the emerging countries, not all of them. For research, we are investing in creating a new research center in Saint Ouen near Paris, which is going to be very important for hair research. We have also invested in the Shanghai, Tokyo, Rio laboratories. In industry, we are building a plant in Russia. We plan to enlarge the plant that we have in Indonesia. We're looking at the possibility of having a plant in the Middle East. So, obviously the investments we are making are also allocated to the development of our presence in these countries.

Well, it doesn't necessarily cost a lot of money to start business Jean-Philippe Blanpain. We have a new low cost plant, low investment cost plant and we're able to set up new plants in new markets, such as Russia, with a very reasonable level of investment, and it is as the capacity ramps up that we invest to assist sales. We're doing what it takes, not in an excessive manner, but we are doing it everywhere to meet the challenge of finding a billion consumers. The billion consumers, for the most part, will come from these new countries, but that is something you know.
A question from the back.
from Euromonitor, and I'll ask my question in English.
Good.

Two questions, one is did you have to utilize price discounts to push sales in the face of the economic downturn and did you think it proved to be useful? And the other question is you are focusing on deodorant and which are the markets are you thinking of sticking to? Thank you.

Okay. Good. Very clear. Price discounts, I would say, honestly, not really, it's a, obviously in the consumer division worldwide, I mean, the 2009 has been a very challenging year and competitive year and it would be – it would not be honest to say that there were no price discount or price promotions. And I'm sure that at Wal-Mart or in Europe we did some price promotions, but Jean-Jacques will tell you that in fact, it was very limited. Jean-Jacques, do you want to say something?

I would say because we've just looked at the numbers of 2009, compared to 2008 and there is a very slight, but it's less than one point, difference in worldwide price promotions. So it's really insignificant in comparison with what you would have thought that a big economic crisis would have generated. There is a very small increase in promotion. It is very small.

By the way it's a very interesting question because I've said in my expose before that in fact, the most surprising factor was that there was no real discount of price of trading down in 2009. I remember one year ago when we met with you or with investors, people were forecasting a kind of Armageddon in term of price falling down, consumption falling down, everything falling down. And in fact, in terms of level of price, honestly nothing happened. It's very interesting to see that in Europe, the hard discounters did not gain market share. In Germany, I guessed right that they even lost market share. That's quite something, interesting, you know. In the private label brands in fact, didn't gain very much.
Yeah, they gained 0.7, not the distributor, own labels in Western Europe gained 0.7 share points they moved from 9.3 to 10.
Yeah, it's nothing.
They are still quite limited and not a big increase. It's a big increase, but still limited.

Yeah. Outside of Spain, because of the special story in Spain, outside of Spain the growth of the private labels in the consumer division markets were plus 4 or 5%, which is absolutely nothing. So the good news is that, honestly, the crisis has not generated a trading down of the markets in 2009 and there is absolutely no reason to think that there will be one in 2010.

So regarding deodorants, we are – it's true that we are now more and more interested in deodorants. It's not the priority number one for us, but it's an opportunity that we want to take, because as I said, in my bad French we want to leverage, add the strength of our research and development, we want to liberate equity of our brands, and we have a beautiful brand called Garnier and this brand is absolutely made for deodorants. And the proof of that is that when we launched Garnier deodorants in Eastern Europe, they took immediately more than 10%. And in Latin America, it's doing very well too. So what we want to do in fact, is just to penetrate a new category and to add a new category in order to generate some incremental business. Okay.
If I may, the first is on SG&A, you've done a decent job in H2 of reducing your costs as a percentage of sales.
Thank you.

Do you expect further improvements going forward, as a percentage of sales? That's the first one. The second one is I believe you've been quoted today in an interview that you no longer think low double-digit EPS growth as guidance is appropriate, I just wanted to check that I've heard that correctly? Thanks.

Yeah, all right. The first question regarding the SG&A, thank you for the decent job and we hope to please you again next year. No, we think honestly that all the measures that we have taken in 2009 will continue to deliver some improvements in the SG&A in terms of ratio. As I have said also, I mean, we did most of the restructuring, or I would say all of it in the next year. So, we don't have any more big restructuring plans for this year. But the big moves that we have made last year are – will deliver in 2010 again. So, we expect our SG&A to be – to do a decent job again.

Regarding the double-digit profit growth what I said very precisely at Reuters is that we don't want to commit to do it every year. Because I think that this was a trap in the previous years and we don't want to fall again in this trap. It doesn't mean that we can't do it. It doesn't mean that we won't do it. It doesn't mean that we are not capable of doing it. It just means that we don't want to fall again in the trap and to be again in a situation where year-after-year, we have to deliver double-digit profit growth. Because some years it's easy or it's good for the company, some years, you can do more, but maybe in some years, you have other choices that are more strategic for the company. And I don't think it's healthy to be stuck like this in this kind of obligation, that's the only thing I said.
But it – I didn't say at all that that we are not maybe able to do it because that's exactly the, I think, the opposite, okay? Monsieur?

You mentioned the mobility of the global cosmetics market and consolidations that may take place. But there may be new competitors arriving on the market. And I'd like to know what you think of Procter & Gamble's present strategy which seems to want to develop in new areas and seems to have very considerable financial resources. Could it be an emerging competitor, so to speak just – and a large competitor?

I don't think they'll be happy if you call them an emerging competitor says Mr. Igel. I don't wish to comment. But, I don't want to comment on my esteemed and respected competitors. But, the great opportunity to take things differently, the great opportunity for L'Oréal is that in all of the emerging markets, there is no major local competitor, we have the usual suspects. The great global players in cosmetics that you all know, no need to say who they are, but we haven't been seeing the emergence of a large new local player in the cosmetics area as we've seen in other areas. When I speak to investors, I tell them that it's a great thing to invest in a company, such as L'Oréal because there is a very low chance that 10 or 20 years from now, it would have to compete with very major competitors from China or India. Cosmetics, in those areas, is not considered as a strategic axis fortunately and these investors will be operating in different areas. So, the field is wide open and it's up to us to play the game well, but the field is open. In all these countries, such as China, India, Brazil, obviously in Brazil there is Natur on a specific circuit, but on all these huge markets so the field is wide open and it's up to us to demonstrate that with our formulas, our products, we are capable of fulfilling the needs and expectations of consumers and I think this is very encouraging for the future. I'm must say that I'm very convinced and of course, believe it or not, I am very convinced that we're on the verge of a new expansion phase for L'Oréal, there was a great expansion phase which followed the fall of the Berlin Wall, or the iron curtain.

In the 90s, the world opened up and we increased from 8% for the new markets to 30% last year and 36% next year. So, there is a new step. These new markets have emerged and from an economic point of view the world of tomorrow is already here, 50% of the market is in those regions, for us it's only 33% right now. So, if we play it right, we have 10 to 20 years of considerable expansion of our business through our brands, through our formulas with our expertise and our know-how in all these countries which are opening up to us and where we can go seeking out these new consumers.

Comment again without a microphone. Once again, if I were to say that they are a new major player they would be a little upset, they would be a little miffed, because they are already big. But regarding the market you were talking about, I was the manager for Asia in '97, we were at zero, three of us were working there. Next year, we will be having €1 billion in sales, we have over 10% of the market if I'm not mistaken, we are number one for hair salons, number one in pharmacies, number one in luxury, number one in popular make-up, number one in skincare, we have 11.7. So the competitor you are mentioning is the P here that you see.

But we are very respectful and we don't give names. So you do see that we have no problem, we are on a nice trend. I'm not saying this in an ironic manner, I respect them as a competitor, they are great people, they believe in the performance of products in research and value, very high quality people, but let the best man win.
If there are no further questions, we may now invite you for drinks and light food. Thank you very much and have a great year.
